ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: huge gain in speaking ability and ability to process news article level difficulty readings
I learned a lot of grammar and vocabulary related to very useful conversational topics.
This course helped me a lot with developing my oral skill and especially becoming comfortable writing essays on topics in Russian based on assignments and class discussions.

Further enhanced Russian language skills -- learned and mastered vocabulary relating to the workforce and education. This course offered practical vocabulary relevant to our lives (i.e. conversations we might actually have if we went abroad).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: loved this course! Irina is phenomenal and improved my Russia so much. Some of the readings were far too difficult which made the course a little unmanageable at times but once that was adjusted to fit the level of the class things were great.
I think this was a very well organized and well taught class.

This course improved a lot over the course of the semester. The professor was very open and adaptive to our wants and suggestions, and changed the course to conform to our interests and abilities. I think perhaps more simplified structure of assignments would have made it feel somewhat less chaotic, but they became more linear and connected over the course of the semester.

Strengths: The course material was structured to fit our needs.

Weakness: Because the syllabus changed a lot, we weren't always sure when assignments were due or what we should prepare for on certain days.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! Irina is one of my favorite professors at Yale and she is incredibly committed to making sure students have what they need to make significant progress in just one semester.

I would recommend this course to any student taking L5 Russian before jumping in to the more text or film based classes. There is a lot of good grammar, vocabulary, and writing skill work that isn't covered in previous classes.
I would absolutely recommend this course to a student considering L5 Russian classes but not comfortable enough in their skills to dive into a literature class. Its a great intermediary step.
